awd_titl_txt: North Star STEM Alliance:  Building on the Legacy of Minnesota's LSAMP
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in their efforts to significantly increase the numbers of students matriculating into and successfully completing high quality degree programs in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines in order to diversify the STEM workforce.  Particular emphasis is placed on transforming undergraduate STEM education through innovative, evidence-based recruitment and retention strategies, and relevant educational experiences in support of racial and ethnic groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African Americans, Hispanic Americans, American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders.  These strategies facilitate the production of well-prepared students highly-qualified and motivated to pursue graduate education or careers in STEM.

For the United States (U.S.) to remain globally competitive, it is vital that it taps into the talent of all its citizens and provides exceptional educational preparedness in STEM areas that underpin the knowledge-based economy.  The North Star STEM Alliance (NSSA) was established in 2007 in response to the need for a more diverse and skilled technical workforce.  That need still exists and is particularly acute in the State of Minnesota.  Participating institutions include three University of Minnesota campuses (Twin Cities, Duluth, and Morris); seven Minnesota State Colleges and Universities (Bemidji State, Century College, Fond du Lac Tribal and Community College, Metropolitan State, Minneapolis Community and Technical College, Minnesota State University Mankato, and St. Cloud State) a tribal college (Leech Lake Tribal College) and three private colleges (Augsburg, Carleton, and St. Olaf).  Community partners include the Science Museum of Minnesota, Minnesota High Tech Association, and the Minnesota Education Equity Partnership.  The goals of NSSA include:  1)Annual completion of 756 underrepresented minority (URM) STEM bachelor's degrees by 2022; 2) Deeper Alliance collaborations to improve students' pathways through all stages of transfer from community colleges to four-year institutions; and 3) Foster institutional change toward greater diversity and inclusion on Alliance campuses.  These goals support the National Science Foundation's strategic goal to "cultivate a world-class, broadly inclusive science and engineering workforce, and expand the scientific literacy of all citizens."  The goals will be accomplished by creating pathways to undergraduate research experiences; group study, supplemental instruction and tutoring; faculty and peer mentoring; community building via cohorts and culturally based STEM student organizations; STEM conference travel; outreach to prospective community college transfer students; and campus climate initiatives.  These activities are expected to produce higher rates of retention and graduation; and moreover, lead to a more talented and diverse STEM workforce.

The knowledge generating research study encompasses a mixed methods research elucidating URM students' science identity development as influenced by research experiences, major and career exploration, mentoring, and co-curricular activities.  The study will provide invaluable insight regarding how URM students can best thrive in programs that aim to support academic and career pathways. Evaluation of the Alliance programming and partnership will take the form of qualitative studies of URM STEM student experiences, Alliance programming, trend analyses of enrollment, retention, engagement, and graduation by URM STEM students; and formative and summative evaluation by an external evaluator.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
The Louis Stokes North Star STEM Alliance (LS-NSSA) aims to increase the number of underrepresented minority (URM) students earning bachelor’s degrees in STEM fields. Participating institutions span three University of Minnesota campuses (Twin Cities, Duluth, and Morris); seven Minnesota state colleges and universities (Bemidji State, Century College, Fond du Lac Tribal and Community College, Metropolitan State, Minneapolis Community and Technical College, Minnesota State University Mankato, and St. Cloud State); two tribal colleges (Fond du Lac Tribal and Community College, Leech Lake Tribal College); and three private colleges and universities (Augsburg, Carleton, and St. Olaf). The Alliance is further supported by two community partners: the Science Museum of Minnesota and the Minnesota High Tech Association.

The following alliance-wide goals were designed to increase the number of STEM degrees earned by students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM fields.

  • Goal 1) Attain 756 underrepresented minority students earning STEM bachelor's degrees annually at Alliance institutions by July 31, 2022,
  • Goal 2) Deepen Alliance collaborations to improve students’ pathways through all transfer stages from community colleges to degrees at 4-year institutions,
  • Goal 3) Foster institutional change toward greater diversity and inclusion on Alliance campuses.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes

Between 2017 and 2023, the North Star STEM Alliance supported 1,849 students who qualified as Level 1 scholars. These students engaged in a range of activities, including mentored research experiences, participation in STEM conferences as attendees and presenters, and involvement in symposia, workshops, and retreats. Scholars funded through the North Star NSF PRELS program undertook year-long mentored academic research projects, engaged in faculty and peer-led professional development, and traveled to STEM conferences.

A study on the impact of North Star STEM programming revealed that participants are better academically and socially prepared to pursue STEM bachelor’s degrees compared to underrepresented minority (URM) students not affiliated with the program. The study also showed that participation enhances students' self-efficacy, interest in STEM, science identity, sense of belonging, and commitment to STEM fields through research and mentorship opportunities. A manuscript detailing these findings is currently under review for publication. Additionally, another research project examines the factors influencing degree attainment and persistence among underrepresented STEM transfer students.

Further insights from North Star STEM programming will be shared through multiple research manuscripts in development. Findings have also been presented at prominent conferences, including the annual meeting of the American Educational Research Association and the annual conference of the National Institute for the Study of Transfer Students.

Broader Impacts Outcomes

Between 2008 and 2023, the annual number of STEM bachelor’s degrees earned by underrepresented minority (URM) students across the Alliance increased steadily from 153 to 708, approaching but not fully reaching the goal of 756 graduates. This shortfall reflects a broader trend of declining graduation rates after 2020, both in Minnesota and nationwide, particularly among URM student populations.

The Alliance developed three signature programs that have had substantial and lasting impacts. These initiatives have been institutionalized across multiple North Star STEM partner institutions, becoming integral to their efforts to support and advance URM students in STEM fields.

Pathways to Research Summer Program – The Alliance developed a research "bootcamp" designed to prepare first- and second-year students with no prior research experience for advanced opportunities in STEM research. The program addresses the research experience gap frequently encountered by underrepresented minority (URM) STEM students. Building on the MnDRIVE program, a cornerstone of the Alliance since 2016, this initiative leverages faculty partnerships to create a pathway program that equips students with the skills and experience needed to pursue more advanced research opportunities.

Indigenous Students Research Retreat - Scholars from multiple North Star STEM Alliance institutions engage in this program, which offers students the opportunity to explore the intersections of Indigenous and Western scientific traditions while developing research projects that integrate both. Program evaluation data shows that participants enhance their research knowledge and skills, particularly in understanding the connections between Western and Indigenous scientific approaches. Additionally, students valued the chance to learn from peers’ life experiences, share research interests, and engage with a community of Indigenous STEM researchers.

Transfer Stakeholder Group - The Transfer Stakeholder Group brings together site coordinators and other transfer stakeholders in order to improve retention rates for students transferring to four-year institutions. Program evaluation involved following up on students who had dropped out/stopped out before the end of three years in order to find out whether these students had re-enrolled in STEM or another major at another institution. The analyses show that some students remain in STEM, but the majority leave higher education. A small portion re-enroll in a 2-year institution. The group is committed to leveraging partnerships within the Alliance to support retention improvements. Annual meetings will serve as a platform for sharing best practices and setting both short- and long-term goals to address these challenges.


Last Modified: 12/31/2024
Modified by: Keisha Varma

por.por_txt_cntn:
The Louis Stokes North Star STEM Alliance (LS-NSSA) aims to increase the number of underrepresented minority (URM) students earning bachelors degrees in STEM fields. Participating institutions span three University of Minnesota campuses (Twin Cities, Duluth, and Morris); seven Minnesota state colleges and universities (Bemidji State, Century College, Fond du Lac Tribal and Community College, Metropolitan State, Minneapolis Community and Technical College, Minnesota State University Mankato, and St. Cloud State); two tribal colleges (Fond du Lac Tribal and Community College, Leech Lake Tribal College); and three private colleges and universities (Augsburg, Carleton, and St. Olaf). The Alliance is further supported by two community partners: the Science Museum of Minnesota and the Minnesota High Tech Association.


The following alliance-wide goals were designed to increase the number of STEM degrees earned by students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM fields.

Goal 1) Attain 756 underrepresented minority students earning STEM bachelor's degrees annually at Alliance institutions by July 31, 2022,
Goal 2) Deepen Alliance collaborations to improve students pathways through all transfer stages from community colleges to degrees at 4-year institutions,
Goal 3) Foster institutional change toward greater diversity and inclusion on Alliance campuses.

The study also showed that participation enhances students' self-efficacy, interest in STEM, science identity, sense of belonging, and commitment to STEM fields through research and mentorship opportunities. A manuscript detailing these findings is currently under review for publication. Findings have also been presented at prominent conferences, including the annual meeting of the American Educational Research Association and the annual conference of the National Institute for the Study of Transfer Students.

Between 2008 and 2023, the annual number of STEM bachelors degrees earned by underrepresented minority (URM) students across the Alliance increased steadily from 153 to 708, approaching but not fully reaching the goal of 756 graduates. This shortfall reflects a broader trend of declining graduation rates after 2020, both in Minnesota and nationwide, particularly among URM student populations.

Program evaluation data shows that participants enhance their research knowledge and skills, particularly in understanding the connections between Western and Indigenous scientific approaches. Additionally, students valued the chance to learn from peers life experiences, share research interests, and engage with a community of Indigenous STEM researchers.

The group is committed to leveraging partnerships within the Alliance to support retention improvements.
